descriptions: The student cannot identify any characteristics of a trusted friend or adult.
The student identifies one or two basic characteristics of a trusted friend or adult.
The student identifies some characteristics, but they are vague or not clearly linked to trust.
The student identifies several relevant characteristics of a trusted friend and adult, providing some explanation.
The student clearly and accurately identifies several important characteristics of a trusted friend and adult, providing good explanations.
The student comprehensively and insightfully identifies key characteristics of a trusted friend and adult, providing detailed explanations and examples.
The student makes no distinction between the characteristics of a trusted friend and a trusted adult.
The student struggles to differentiate between the characteristics of a trusted friend and adult.
The student attempts to differentiate between friend and adult characteristics, but the distinctions are unclear.
The student identifies some differences between the characteristics of a trusted friend and adult.
The student clearly distinguishes between the characteristics of a trusted friend and adult, providing relevant explanations.
The student clearly and insightfully distinguishes between the characteristics of a trusted friend and adult, explaining the reasons for these differences.
The student does not connect the characteristics to health or well-being.
The student vaguely mentions a connection to health or well-being.
The student makes a superficial connection between some characteristics and health or well-being.
The student explains how several characteristics relate to health and well-being.
The student clearly explains how the identified characteristics are important for maintaining health and well-being.

The student provides a comprehensive and insightful explanation of how the characteristics of trusted friends and adults contribute to overall health and well-being, including mental and emotional aspects.
